page.title: 01THE CLAPPERS
page.content: The Clappers is a prominent spur of the Chiltern Hills. The top is crowned with beech trees, which were planted together with some conifers, during the 19th century. The sides are covered{with fairly thick scrub which grew considerably after the rabbit population had been decimated by the introduction of myxamatosis in the l960's. Rabbits are now breeding in the area. This local landmark was donated by the W A Robertson Memorial Fund, in 1939, to the National Trust. His mother wished to commemorate the death of her son who was killed in the First World War. Since that time the site has been administered by the Trust. In recent years a number of improvements have been made.At the entrance to the site
